Award.AwardTitle: Planning IUCRC at Northeastern University: Center for Solid-State Green Electric Power Generation and Storage (CEPS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF IUCRC Center for Solid-State Green Electric Power Generation and Storage (CEPS) is based on long-term partnerships between universities, industry, national laboratories, and state and federal institutions. The IUCRC CEPS goal is focused on fundamental mechanisms of novel superfast solid-state glass-ceramic conductors and on correlation of these mechanisms with respect to corresponding solid-state energy storage. The IUCRC CEPS will advance the NSF mission by expanding fundamental scientific knowledge related to charge transfer in solid state applications. IUCRC CEPS will provide solutions for safe, high efficiency, and eco-friendly sustainable energy storage leading to energy security, stronger national defense, and advancements in the interests of national health. The role of the SDSMT center is to develop the next generation of solid-state energy storage architectures through a fundamental understanding of structure-property relationships. The SDSMT center effort is focused on alternative solid-state deposition approaches that will provide a cutting edge strategy for manufacturing of solid-state energy storage devices. The faculty associated with SDSMT center will advance the NSF mission of diversity by mentoring young scientists and minority students, and providing broad multidisciplinary educational experience.

The prospective Center focuses on advancing understanding of fundamental mechanisms that take place in novel superfast solid-state glass-ceramic conductors under electric transient conditions and correlation of these mechanisms with the corresponding transport mechanisms for high efficiency, safe, and environmentally friendly all-solid-state energy technology. New knowledge and scientific contributions to the field of solid-state ionics will be generated through the following: 1) Mechanisms of micro- and nanostructural evolution of novel nano-architectures at atomic scale; 2) Understanding mass and charge transfer mechanisms by in-situ operando studies; 3) Self-charging mechanisms within intrinsically integrated solid-state energy storage multilayer structures involving perovskite solar cells; 4) New miniaturization technology leading to safe, human-friendly, and long-lasting solid-state energy storage systems for medical applications; and 5) Solid-state energy storage integration into green power generation systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IUCRC Center for Solid-State Green Electric Power Generation and Storage (CEPS) brought together administration, faculty, students, and entrepreneurs from Northeastern University (NEU) in Boston, MA and the three major South Dakota (SD) universities, specifically SD School of Mines and Technology (SDSMT), University of South Dakota (USD), SD State University (SDSU).

The cross-cutting effort and the overarching goal of the IUCRC Center for Solid-State Green Electric PowerGeneration and Storage (CEPS) was to accelerate transition to eco-friendly, safe, and economically feasible all-solid-state energy storage technology for use in portable, medical, automotive, electric power grid, and military applications. Other specific CEPS goals involved strong engagement of industry and academia, workforce development, contribution to growing strategically vital sector of the energy economy, and strong outreach to Underrepresented Minority (URM) groups. These goals were met in direct compliance withthe DOE 2020 announcement of the "Energy Storage Grand Challenge" and include: (1) Technology development, (2) Technology transfer, (3) Policy and valuation, (4) Manufacturing and supply chain, and (5)Workforce. The CEPS management team intends to aggressively pursue participation in this new DOE initiative to supplement the funding available through the NSF IUCRU program.

Within the project, IUCRC CEPS met specific objectives such as:

(1) Identified the major economy sectors within the U.S. and internationally that need safe and reliable energy storage. These sectors were identified by using extensive Internet search, participation in five international conferences, providing over 300 discovery interviews, and communication through social mediaplatforms: Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, LinkedIn and SnapChat. For example, total number of followers for Instagram, Facebook, LinkedIn and Twitter is exceeded 69,000. From January 2019 to January 2020, total followers to all platforms grew 61.7%. Total impressions for the same period was 9,454,240, which was an increase of 40.3%. Engagement for the platforms was 542,668 which was an increase of 47.3%.

(2) Within each sector, identified the specific companies and their interests that are in line with CEPS shortand long-term objectives, such as industry-academia engagement, growth, and sustainability.

(3) Stimulated engagement of industry, national labs, and federal agencies by broad participation in the Planning Grant Meeting that attracted over 100 attendees , and growth of the number of CEPS potentialmembers.

(4) Embraced broad dissemination methodology by using GreenCEPS.com website capabilities, use of social networks, and presentations at the conferences for strong long-term engagement and involvement of newfaculty, students, and stuff from the four university sites.

The major CEPS activities involved: (1) Weekly online web meetings, (2) Creation and regular updates ofthe GreenCEPS website, (3) Preparation and execution of the Planning Grant Meeting, (4) Discoveryinterviews with potential CEPS members, (5) Broadcasting and involvement of social media, and (6) FollowupPlanning Grant meetings with representatives from industry, national labs, and federal agencies. As aresult, a database of individual contacts including 200+ companies within the specific economy sectors wascreated. However, the targeting remains relatively broad since almost every economy sector rely on energystorage, and CEPS activities could be attractive for many companies in the U.S. and around the world.

The Planning Grant Meeting was the major outcome of this project. The registration for the CEPS PlanningGrant meeting was available on online at www.GreenCEPS.com. Among over 100 attendees participated inthe Planning Grant Meeting, 47 of them represented industry, federal agencies and National labs. A fewattendees obtained a permission to access the meeting remotely in real time using Zoom.com and BlueJeans.com videoconferencing services. Significant help inpreparation for the Planning Grant Meeting was received from the SDSMT undergraduate students. Theywere involved in printing out and assembling the folders, preparing badges, and answering the questionsfrom the CEPS meeting attendees.

The CEPS project provided broad opportunities for faculty, stuff, and studetns to be directly engaged indiscussions and collaboration with both small start-ups and big companies that are pursuing the same goal of sustainable and safe energy storage. Besides professional development, the project cultivated an inclusiveclimate to support underrepresented populations, foster respect for those with diverse backgrounds, and promote cultural proficiency among faculty, staff and students. CEPS goal was to promote a culture of respect, honor, understanding, integrity, and collaboration. It is through this diversity and inclusion that CEPS found its strength.
